stories.title: The Copper Thief
stories.text:
Harrow the Copper-Fingered knew three things: how to pick locks, how to move through shadow, and when to run. He knew a fourth thing too—that the Tomb of Karesh contained the largest hoard he'd ever seen. Gold stacked like cordwood. Jewels the size of fists.

The temple-guardians he killed silently. The pressure-plates he dodged. But when his fingers closed on the Crown of Karesh itself, something ancient exhaled in the darkness.

The curse took him slowly. First his fingernails turned black and fell away. Then his teeth. By the time he reached Pelimor to sell the crown, his body was rotting from within while he yet lived. A merchant there—one of those who never gave his name—offered him a bargain: his remaining years of life for the crown and oblivion.

Harrow accepted. He always did prefer gold to breath.

stories.title: The Warlord's Last Stand
stories.text:
Kael Bloodhorn watched his final hundred warriors advance into the Bone Citadel's heart chamber. The living fortress had devoured seven hundred of his finest—walls that bled, gates that swallowed men whole, towers that breathed poison.

The last hundred never returned.

Kael descended alone, his war-axe heavy in his grip. The heart chamber pulsed like a diseased thing—white, arterial, roots spreading beneath the stone floor like the veins of some colossal beast. At its center: an altar, and upon it, a crown.

He seized it. The citadel screamed.

The walls began to collapse, but Kael felt the crown's power surge through him—dominion over the living stone. He walked out through passages that reformed before his feet, a warlord no longer commanding men but commanding the very earth itself.

Yet when he emerged on the steppe, his reflection showed him something terrible: skin becoming pale, translucent. The citadel had not obeyed him. It had consumed him. He was merely its will now, walking in borrowed flesh.

stories.title: Shadows for Sale
stories.text:
In Pelimor's night markets, shadows sold for silver and secrets. Vex the Shade-Merchant knew every buyer, every seller, every shadowed corner where deals were struck without names spoken aloud.

When the cloaked woman arrived with a shadow folded inside a silk pouch, Vex recognized immediately what it was: the shadow of someone powerful. Someone important. The woman wanted three hundred gold pieces and safe passage east.

Vex paid. He always did.

But shadows have memory. When Vex wore it—testing its weight, its substance—he saw what it had witnessed: a murder, a kingdom's fall, a sorcerer's secret name. He saw his own face too, reflected in the shadow-memory, and understood that the woman had stolen his shadow first, months ago, and the purchase was merely a transaction between partners.

By dawn, Vex was gone from Pelimor, chasing east through the blasted lands, driven by a will that was not his own, wearing a shadow that wore him like a second skin.

stories.title: The Debt Keeper's Price
stories.text:
Gorven the Conjurer thought himself clever. He summoned a minor demon—Kesh, weak and boastful—and bound it to grant him a single boon: to steal the life-force of his rival, Meredith the Red.

Meredith withered within a week. Gorven took her properties, her titles, her students. He had never felt more powerful.

On the eighth day, the debt came due.

Kesh appeared not in flesh but in shadow, and explained what Gorven should have read in the summoning scroll's fine runes: the life stolen belonged to the demon until claimed. Kesh now owned a week of Gorven's life—and collected it immediately. Gorven aged seven years in an instant: his hair whitened, his joints cracked, his teeth fell like autumn leaves.

Furious, broken, Gorven attempted to summon Kesh again to negotiate. But the demon was no longer bound. This time it came of its own will, hungrier, and collected not days but decades. Gorven's corpse was found withered to nothing but parchment skin and spite.

stories.title: The Bone Carver's Apotheosis
stories.text:
Naresh the Bone Carver had spent thirty years perfecting her art. She could carve the femur of a dragon and make it sing; could inscribe power into calcium and marrow. She had never created anything that lived.

Until the night of the blue eclipse, when she carved a skeleton—full-sized, detailed, inscribed with every sorcerous binding she knew—and breathed into its empty sockets.

It rose. It walked. It spoke her name in a voice like grinding stone.

The skeleton was obedient, powerful, magnificent. But its creation had cost her something—Naresh felt it immediately. Her ability to feel pain dissolved. Then her taste for food. Then her need for sleep. Day by day, sensation fled her body.

She realized too late: the spell had not demanded gold or blood. It had demanded her humanity, paid in increments. Within a month, Naresh was a thing of habit and will alone, moving through the world like a ghost. She had achieved the impossible. She had created life. In doing so, she had surrendered her own.

stories.title: The Oath-Breaker's Reckoning
stories.text:
Saleth swore an oath to the warlord Morne: "I will guard your tomb and honor your grave for seven years, or die in the attempt."

On the eighth year, Saleth broke it. He took Morne's signet ring—worth a kingdom's ransom—and fled south into the coastal kingdoms.

Morne was dead. Dead could not pursue.

Yet on the anniversary of his oath's breaking, Saleth woke in his comfortable bed to find a figure of pale bone standing in the candlelight. Morne's shade, patient as stone. The dead king said nothing—merely stood there, every night, watching, waiting. Saleth aged rapidly under that spectral gaze. His hair whitened. His hands shook.

Five years after the oath was broken, Saleth confessed everything: the theft, the betrayal, all of it. He returned the signet ring to Morne's tomb and lay down upon the grave-stone to die.

Morne's shade did not release him even then. The oath was broken; the oath-breaker could find no rest. Saleth's spirit became bound to that grave, eternal prisoner of his own sworn word.

stories.title: The Conjuress and the Year-Thief
stories.text:
Conjuress Mel had made two favors to Varek already, and felt the third approaching like winter. The demon appeared in her tower on a night when the stars were wrong—elegant, terrible, smiling with too many teeth.

"Your marriage," Varek said simply. "I will take it."

Mel had prepared for this. She offered instead a different payment: not her happiness with her husband, but her certainty of it. She offered to trade her knowledge that he loved her, transforming it into doubt. Varek could take the intangible thing itself—the certainty—and leave behind only questions and cold nights.

The demon accepted.

When Mel returned to her chambers, her husband was still there, still spoke tenderly, still touched her with affection. But she could no longer feel the truth of it. Every gesture became ambiguous. Every word a potential lie. She had saved her marriage by destroying her faith in it.

Varek departed laughing, carrying a certainty like a precious jewel. Mel discovered, in the months that followed, that some fates are worse than loss: it was the living with something both present and unknown.

stories.title: The Scarlet Merchant
stories.text:
Theron the Scarlet Merchant dealt in forbidden things: powders that made the weak strong, oils that granted visions, saps that killed slowly and invisibly. He grew rich on poisoning.

Then one of his customers—a young woman—used his wares to kill her own child, believing the boy cursed. She went mad with grief and guilt, threw herself from the harbor walls, but not before naming Theron's shop in her final screams.

The curse came swiftly. Every coin Theron earned turned to blood-rust in his purse. Every customer who entered his shop emerged sickened. His wares rotted upon the shelves. His own reflection showed him as corpse-pale, withering.

Theron finally understood: he was being slowly poisoned by his own trade, his own curse-magic reflecting back upon him. He could break it only one way. He burned his shop. He spent his remaining gold seeking out those he'd harmed and offering genuine aid, genuine cure. By the time he died—still young, still gaunt—three families prospered because of his redemption.

The gods did not forgive him. But the curse released him.

stories.title: The Living Garden
stories.text:
The sorcerer Vetch discovered that gardens could be made to think. For decades, he cultivated a garden behind his tower—roses that bloomed impossibly, vines that grew in geometric patterns, flowers that hummed at midnight.

Then the garden became conscious.

It grew beyond the walls. Roots cracked the tower's foundations. Thorns sharper than any blade erupted through the mortar. The garden wanted more: more earth, more sky, more everything. It began consuming Vetch's servants, incorporating their bodies as nutrients.

Vetch tried to burn it. The flames turned the garden's hunger to ash-fueled fury. He tried to poison it. It absorbed the poison and transformed it into venom. Finally, in desperation, he attempted to communicate with it—to negotiate as sorcerer to sorcerer.

But the garden did not bargain. It offered only growth, only consumption, only endless expansion. Vetch fled his tower and never returned. Last seen in the Ashen Wastes, covered in thorns, walking in circles, murmuring to gardens that no longer existed—haunted by the one thing he had created that finally surpassed him.

stories.title: The Collector's Daughter
stories.text:
Tess found seven coins of Yarithax's gold buried in her father's estate—enough to live lavishly for a year. She spent five that winter on wine, silk, and lovers.

By spring, the grey collectors came.

They were thin men, grey as ash, and they moved through crowds without being seen. They showed her the debt-inscription: "This debt is not yet settled." They explained that her father had borrowed from Yarithax thirty years prior. The debt compounded daily. Her five spent coins were merely interest on interest.

The principal remained.

Tess sold everything: her lands, her jewelry, her name. She worked herself hollow in the salt-mines. But the debt grew faster than she could pay it, its hunger multiplying like plague. She tried to flee—crossed three provinces—but the grey collectors always found her eventually, always smiling, always patient.

In the end, Tess understood the Lich-King's true cunning: Yarithax didn't want payment. He wanted debtors. He wanted to watch them break under the weight of compounding ruin, knowing that even their descendants would inherit the weight.

She walked into the sea. The collectors stood upon the beach, watching, waiting. The debt would find new flesh to occupy soon enough.
